summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Minnesota today entered a final judgment against Jason Lewandowski, a former Day County Sheriff, who was convicted of first- and second-degree felony murder, commission of a felony while armed with a firearm, and burglary in the first degree stemming from the shooting death of Jeremy Hendrickson (Jeremy).  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Fargo, North Dakota, alleges that, on July 21, 2012, Lewandowski claimed he aggravated his injuries when he tripped and fell in a ditch after deer hunting.  According to the complaint, after learning about the shooting, he confronted his brother about it and confronted him about it.  The complaint alleges that Lewandowski replied, “I'm sorry, sorry man,” put his.22 caliber pistol to Jeremy’s head and shot him in the head.  In a parallel action, on December 9, 2015, a federal district court in Dayton, North Carolina, entered a judgment against Lewandowski that permanently enjoins him from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, a civil penalty, and an officer-and-director bar.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, the defendant consented to the entry of a judgment permanently enjoining him from future violations of the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, ordering him to comply with the court order, and imposing a $25,000 civil penalty against him.  On November 20, 2015 Lewandowski allegedly told his attorney that he was going to the hospital to help support his back and knee and had two drinks.  He also claimed that the State improperly withdrew the plea agreement later that evening after the victim's family objected to the terms of the agreement.  Finally, he claimed that he had a continuing "right to remain silent and stop questioning at any time."  The court found that the state breached a plea agreement at the time it entered the agreement, and that it should have suppressed the statements he made to Lunzman on the night of the shooting.  As alleged in the SEC complaint, however, the state failed to adequately consider Lewandowski's intoxication and impaired mental state in its decision to suppress those statements.  For example, the SEC alleges that the defendant had previously waived his Miranda rights and was not suffering from any hallucinations or delusions when he was questioned by Lunzman.  Instead, the court determined that the defendants violated the right against self-incrimination and ordered the state to
